thread.title_full: Who Wants to Ring the Closing Bell on Stock Market’s Bad Days? - WSJ

author: Mike Vilensky
title: Who Wants to Ring the Closing Bell on Stock Market’s Bad Days?
text:
1 COMMENTS As the trading day came to an end on Aug. 24, with U.S. stocks down nearly 600 points, there was perhaps no more welcome sight than the executives at Cash America International Inc., CSH 3.17 % a publicly traded pawnshop company scheduled to ring the New York Stock Exchange’s closing bell.
“I think a lot of people were happy to see the exchange close that day,” said Yolanda Walker, the Fort Worth, Texas-based company’s vice president of public relations.
ENLARGE NYSE bell In the tumultuous days recently, as markets have slid, the job of closing-bell ringer has taken an anxious turn. During tough times, the corporate executives, celebrities and other guests who have assumed the ceremonial assignment can find themselves in an awkward position: putting the cap on a day of economic upheaval while smiling brightly.
“I think we were bringing hope,” said Salome Gudmundsdottir, chief executive of a startup support group called Klak Innovit who rang the Nasdaq NDAQ 1.52 % Stock Market closing bell on Aug. 25, another down day. “A light in the dark.”
Past closing-bell ringers with the bad luck of closing a down day can remember the anxiety, as well as the pressure to keep up appearances.
“I hate those days,” said Matt Tuttle, a financial adviser who rang the Nasdaq closing bell on July 8, when the markets were rattled by an apparent technical glitch that had halted trading at the New York Stock Exchange. “You’ve got that feeling in the pit of your stomach.”
As the person officiating at the market’s close in a televised ceremony, however, “I was more worried to make sure I smile,” he said. “That was my focus: Remember to smile.”
At times, being upbeat feels incongruous with the market’s reality.
“It was funny: On a down day, they’d all clap and cheer, but they had this fake plastic look on their faces, like ‘The market just lost 1,000 points!’” said Chris Foley, a stockbroker-turned-actor. “They’d go ‘yay,’ but if it’s down a lot, they know.”
While he hasn’t rung the bell himself, he has some advice for those who do. The opening one “is safer,” he said. “You don’t know what the market’s going to do.”
Guests on down days had varied takes on the experience. Some hoped to project calm amid financial fears. Others saw the glass half-full: On a bad day of newsworthy proportions, their appearance got more attention.
Most vowed not to let a little thing like a market plunge get between them and their big moment.
“Our focus was celebrating 25 years, and we weren’t about to let anything ruin that moment of history for us when we were smiling up on the platform,” said Cash America’s Ms. Walker, whose company has been on the exchange for a quarter-century. “It was just one of those moments of irony. I’m sure there were people watching closely, but we were caught up in the nostalgia of the day.”
Browse Recent A-heds ENLARGE Where Do the Indian and Atlantic Oceans Meet? Japan’s Most Powerful Follow the Sensei of Seaweed Muslim Teen Wrestler ‘Joelle’ Busts Barriers in the Gulf The following day, markets rallied but fell again, sparking anxieties about an economic rut.
Hedge-funder Sonia Gardner, who rang the closing bell at the NYSE on Aug. 25 on behalf of 100 Women in Hedge Funds, saw a potential upside, though.
Awareness of her nonprofit organization, which supports women in finance, “may have been heightened by the fact that so many people were focused on the market volatility and the close of trading that day,” she said.
Some guests got more than they bargained for.
Actress Missi Pyle was scheduled to close the markets on Sept. 29, 2008, which later became known as one of the worst days in financial history.
“I was so excited to do it. I was doing this play on Broadway, and the publicist said, ‘You can go and ring the closing bell,’ ” she said. Once the day arrived, however, “an hour beforehand, they were like, ‘You know what? We don’t want you to have to be associated with this terrible day.’ ”
A NYSE official stood in for Ms. Pyle instead, but her affiliation with the close “is on my IMDb page now, it’s my top news story,” she said. “I can’t escape it!”
Bells came into use in the late 1800s to signal the start and end of the day, as continuous trading markets emerged and officials sought to maintain an orderly schedule. The first NYSE guest bell-ringer was in the 1950s, but it wasn’t until the 1990s that guest ringers became a staple at both Nasdaq and the NYSE. Though corporate executives are frequent bell-ringers, at the NYSE, ballerina Misty Copeland, singer Jordin Sparks, and astronaut Joseph Acaba have recently done the honors.
Much work goes into the ceremonies, market officials said, though they only last a fleeting few minutes. At the NYSE, the bell-ringer presses a button and pounds a gavel, while a digital bell is pressed on a tablet at Nasdaq.
“I don’t think there’s a great amount of volatility between a day that’s up or down,” said Robert H. McCooey Jr., a senior vice president at Nasdaq. “It’s really about the company coming in and celebrating that milestone.” Garvis Toler, global head of capital markets for the New York Stock Exchange, said “bell-ringers are in that moment, taking in the experience. It’s less important what the markets are doing that particular day.”
George Arzt, a public-relations executive and former press secretary for late New York City Mayor Ed Koch, said even with the potential for a down day, ringing the bell holds a unique allure as part of a press tour.
“It’s your 15 seconds of fame,” he said.
But he would prefer his client nab an opening-bell spot. “By the closing bell, people are just glad to get out of there,” he said, “especially in the last few days.”
On Wednesday, stocks rebounded after volatile days, and Ken Kannappan, chief executive of audio communications company Plantronics, rang the bell joyously at the New York Stock Exchange.
“That’s an added boost,” he said afterward, of the market jump. “But it would have been a great occasion for us anyway.”
